results.description:
Hello Free-Writing Women!

We have another two Women's Writing Circles (WWCs) scheduled for next week!  Timed to coincide with Valentine's Day, the theme is "Love & Heartache!"

Research shows that writing about our emotions and listening to personal narratives improves our health AND helps us to make sense of our lives! And we feel a stronger sense of connection to others through sharing our stories.


Both will be held on Monday, February 8th at Suffolk University in Boston (1-3pm and 5:30-7:30pm), located just 2 blocks from the Park Street 'T' stop with metered street parking and ample parking in nearby garages. 

The cost is FREE, as they are sponsored by The Center for Women's Health & Human Rights (CWHHR) at Suffolk University.  Registration, however is required.  Limited to 8 people, so if you know you are interested, please register soon as registration is already underway and filling up (some people do not use Meet-Up, so even though it looks like there are many spots left, there aren't!).  Also, please do not sign up unless you intend to come!

To officially register, go here: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/womens-writing-circle-tickets-18974576469

Hope to see you there!

Jennifer A. Minotti, M.A., Ed.M.
Visiting Artist
Women's Writing Circle: The Center for Women's Health & Human Rights
Suffolk University
73 Tremont Street, 5th Floor
Boston, MA 02018

results.description:
Release Date:

February 12, 2016

Rating: R

Synopsis:

There’s a right way to be single, a wrong way to be single, and then…there’s Alice. And Robin. Lucy. Meg. Tom. Ken. David. Josh. George. New York City is full of fun seekers seeing the right match, be it a love connection, a hook-up, or something in the middle. And somewhere between the late night date nights, teasing texts and one-night stands, what these unmarrieds all have in common is the need to learn how to be single in a world filled with ever-evolving definitions of love. So whether you make it a dinner-and-movie date night or a girls’ night out, “How to be Single” will show you that sleeping around in the city that never sleeps has never been so much fun!

RATED: R for sexual content and strong language throughout.


https://youtu.be/akwGjUeU6YA

results.description:
Our speaker will be Harvard 300th Anniversary History Professor

Laurel Ulrich

Laurel is an unusual and fascinating historian who unlocks history from unexpected things (a hundred year old tortilla?) In her words “the real drama is in the humdrum.” Among other books she wrote "Well behaved women seldom make history! Her talk to the Economy Club will focus on, Tangible Things: Making History through Objects (2015), a book she co-authored with several colleagues who collaborated on a 2010 museum exhibit of little-known objects in Harvard’s collection.

“Over four centuries, Harvard University has amassed an astonishing array of tangible things. The university not only owns a Gutenberg bible, but samples of nineteenth-century “spirit writing” chalked on a child-sized slates. Tucked away in its storage cabinets are Henry David Thoreau’s pencil, chemicals captured from a Confederate ship, and an intact Mexican tortilla more than a century old. By learning how and why such things got here, you will discover how material objects have shaped academic disciplines. You might also discovery the ways in which things in your own cupboards and attics reveal forgotten aspects of history. “

Laurel

Laurel is 300th Anniversary University Professor at Harvard University. She received her doctorate at the University of New Hampshire where she began her teaching career in history before moving to Harvard. Laurel is also a prolific author. Her book, A Midwife’s Tale, won the Pulitzer Prize, in addition to other prizes and honors. A version of the book aired in the PBS series, “The American Experience”. Among Laurel’s other publications are The Age of Homespun: Objects and Stories in the Creation of an American Myth (2001). Her books often focus on the experience of ordinary people rather than the famous.

About the Dinner: Usually about 20 to 35 people composed of members and meetup invitees.

Social Hour: 6:00 p.m. Dinner: 6:30 p.m. Speaker : Around 8 p.m. You can come at any time.

RISTORANTE GRAN GUSTO

We have negotiated two reduced (!) price dinners. However if neither of these suit you you can order separately from their menu or not at all!

The two dinner choices are: A many(!) course Italian dinner at $36.00 or a pizza, appetizer, salad and desert dinner at $24.00. (The pizza is real authentic Italian pizza!) (tip included!) Or you can join the club and pay less per dinner!

Drinks can be ordered from the bar.
results.name: History Illuminated and Dinner!

results.description:
Mandarin Conversation group Meetup.


Feel free to bring Snacks, drinks or take out to share with others.  We like to have food with our meetings. Bring some cash if you want to go out to eat afterward.

2nd Monday meetings to practice Mandarin conversation. Learners of all levels, and native speakers welcome!
This is an opportunity to meet with other learners and practice whatever you'd like to work on. Bring any books or homework you would like to review, and ask a native speaker to help you with pronunciation.

Hopefully we will try translate and read a song or poem or something in Chinese with pin yin.

Adele

---
------------
DIRECTIONS: (a member says that Mapquest directions are confusing)
BCNC is at 38 Ash St., off of Oak St. between Washington St. and Harrison Ave.
Oak St. is between Kneeland St. and Marginal Way (alongside the Turnpike)

The closest T stop is Orange Line New England Medical Center.
Walk toward the South End (away from Chinatown) on Washington St and take the first left onto Oak St. The entrance to the building is in Ash St., the first small street on the left. There's a sign for BCNC- Boston Chinatown Neighborhood Center. Sign in at the front desk and ask for the Meetup conversation group.
Parking is limited in the area, due to the theater district, but sometimes you can find spaces on the surrounding blocks. There are pay lots on Kneeland and Tremont Streets.
The phone number in case you get lost is[masked]-5129.

For more information, see <a>http://www.bcnc.net.....</a>;.


------------

Kitty Whist Night:

New players VERY welcome:

We will teach you how to play.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge, however It is suggested that you buy a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment.

Menu:

http://www.bertuccis.com/?gclid=CMi-r4DA-sgCFZGRHwodTLIMaw#menu


A drink meal and tip could be $20 - $30

New people are very welcome and will probably will play their first few hands, about an hour of instruction, with the Meetup organizer and selected players before playing at-large with the rest of the group.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to bid or play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced and considerate of everyone between the two activities.


https://www.google.com/maps/@42.4836419,-70.905886,17z?hl=en

Same lot as Stop and Shop next to Walgreen's.

results.description:
Ryan Prescott Adams: Using Intelligent Algorithms to Design Intelligent Algorithms

Meet us Monday, February 8 at 7pm at The Burren in Davis Square!

Ryan is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at Harvard University. He teaches courses in artificial intelligence and machine learning. His leads the Harvard Intelligent Probabilistic Systems (HIPS) research group and is a co-founder of Whetlab, a machine learning startup. If you are interested in these topics, you can also find him discussing the field a podcast (“Talking Machines“) with Katherine Gorman.


Science by the Pint is sponsored by an organization of Harvard graduate students called Science in the News. In between their sleepless hours of hard work at Harvard Med School, they bring cutting edge scientific research to the public in a fun and informal format. The Burren is located on Elm Street right in the heart of Davis Square, just a short walk from the Red Line stop. If you prefer to drive, there are metered spots on the street and in nearby municipal lots (see link below). Meters are active until 8:00 PM, and metered spots are free thereafter. Municipal lot meters are good for three hours, and street spots are good for two.

Links:

"Talking Machines" podcast

SITN Facebook Page

SITN: Science by the Pint

The Burren

Davis Square Parking
results.name: Science by the Pint: Intelligent Algorithms Designing Intelligent Algorithms

results.description:
This is the final Meetup for studying Ray Kurzweil's book,  The Singularity is Near. We will look at chapter 9, in which he answers his critics. If you're one of them, attend and hear him out!


****************************************


ADMISSION FEE: Bronze and Gold Members are admitted free. Basic members are required to pay a $5.50 admission fee, which is due on or before Friday, January 29th. PLEASE PAY HERE. Any unpaid registration (RSVP) as of January 30th will be changed to "not attending." Afterwards, you may re-register your RSVP to “Yes, attending” but you must first process your payment.


Gold and Bronze Memberships entitle you to attend great events such as Impromptu Philosophizers, study group meetings and more! Instead of paying the admission fee, you can purchase a paid membership (for as little as $15 per year) on the Membership Page .


****************************************


The obvious criticisms of Kurzweil's thesis include


• The exponential growth in technology must come to an end at some point!


• The human brain is just too complex to be modeled in software.


• There's just no way a computer can be conscious!


• If all else succeeds, the government will ensure failure.

Kurzweil considers these and more. Bring your own criticism and an appetite for lively discussion.
results.name: Futurology Study Group: Response to Kurzweil's Critics

results.description:
Weather.  Please pay attention to weather conditions and use best judgement.  I will be here and the snow plowing company should clean by 5pm.  However, use best judgement.  I would rather have you alive so that we can play many games for years.

======

Notice the change of day for this particular event: Monday.  We are going to try to do some of the Tuesdays at Adam's house (with a Monday event at my house this same week).  Hopefully we get more gaming options and more people can participate in at least one of the events.

===========


Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.

results.description:
Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University presents a lecture by Robin W. Cotton, associate professor and director, Biomedical Forensic Sciences, Boston University School of Medicine

https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/event/2016-robin-w-cotton-lecture 

The use of DNA for the analysis of biological evidence began in the US in 1987 and has had a positive and permanent effect on all forensic testing. DNA testing has lead in development of standards for forensic laboratory testing, and standards for all types of forensic testing are currently being developed thru the NIST Organization of Scientific Area Committees.

http://www.nist.gov/forensics/osac/index.cfm

Rapid non-laboratory based DNA testing equipment and DNA sequencing methods for forensic application, along with the associated “big data," will present the next methodological changes and challenges. However, the roughness of the intersection between science and law has not significantly improved and continues to challenge forensic science practitioners and lawyers representing both the defense and prosecution sides of criminal cases. This talk will review current scientific and laboratory challenges and discuss the issues encountered when forensic scientists, lawyers, and judges all try to “do the right thing” together.

Speaker:

Robin W. Cotton, Associate Professor and Director, Biomedical Forensic Sciences, Boston University School of Medicine

This event is free and open to the public. Doors open at 4:45 p.m.; lecture begins at 5 p.m.

Videos:

DNA Symposium | Forensic DNA Investigation https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/video/dna-symposium-forensic-dna-investigation

DNA Symposium | The Ethical Frontier of DNA : https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/video/dna-symposium-ethical-frontier-dna 

DNA Symposium | The Future Utility of DNA Science https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/video/dna-symposium-future-utility-dna-science
results.name: Forensic DNA Testing: Why Are There Still Bumps in the Road?

:: :: ::

The use of DNA for the analysis of biological evidence has had a positive and permanent effect on all forensic testing. However, hurdles remain as the intersection between science and law has not significantly improved and continues to challenge forensic science practitioners and lawyers representing both sides of criminal cases. This talk with review current scientific and laboratory challenges and discuss the issues encountered when forensic scientists, lawyers, and judges all try to “do the right thing” together.

results.description:
After a busy holiday season, BGN is back and bigger than ever!


BGN Fans,  


We're excited to bring you February's Board Game Night, as always hosted by East Coast Product, and this month sponsored by WeWork, Downeast Cider House, Cape Ann Brewing Co., Fort Point Legal, Sweetgreen,  and Startup Institute. We are jam packed with giveaways so each +1 guest you bring you earn an additional entry!

Your $5 registration includes drinks and snacks. All proceeds benefit the ever awesome Resilient Coders, an organization dedicated to making web tech education more accessible to urban youth. WeWork has offered to match every donation so your $5 donation is going a lot further.

Half-networking, half-gaming -- it's the only event in Boston that brings together innovation enthusiasts for an evening of friendly competition and great conversation. Don't forget to spread the word use the hashtag #BGNio9 and tweet us @BGNio to stay in the loop and build our community.

Our games include:

• Settlers of Catan

• Race to the Galaxy

• Dominion

• Marvel Legendary

• Succession

• Puerto Rico

• DiXit

• San Juan

• Indie Game Spotlight: Move Rate 20's: Master of Spies 


• Or bring your own! 

SPONSORS

East Coast Product is the fastest most efficient way to build the right digital product to get your startup to it's next milestone. We are a product accelerator specializing in growth stage startups, helping them through strategy and execution. 

Fort Point Legal represents the entrepreneur community, acting as a trusted advisor to founders so that legal decisions promote the business and strategy goals of our clients. We offer business & corporate legal support, as well as commercial real estate expertise.

WeWork is the community for creators. We transform buildings into beautiful, collaborative workspaces and provide infrastructure, services, events and technology so our members can focus on doing what they love. We currently have 56 locations in 16 cities and 35,000 members! Book a tour at wework.com


sweetgreen is a destination for simple, seasonal, healthy food. We believe the choices we make every day about what we eat, where it comes from, and how it’s made have a lasting impact on our communities. 

Our eight-week program will give you the skills, mindset, and network to find a job you love, doing work that matters.

We’ll help you leverage your passions and build the technical skills, culture skills, and network that will launch you into the innovation industry in the areas of web development, web design, technical marketing, or sales and account management.

Uniquely positioned at the center of tech ecosystems in Boston, New York, and Chicago, we’ve designed our program to open new doors for you. In addition to expert training in the most in-demand skills, we offer personalized career mentorship and connections to the people and companies that will advance your career.

Founded in 2004, Cape Ann Brewing Company is an award-winning, family-owned, micro-brewery in the heart of the historic seaport of Gloucester in Cape Ann. Brewing beer whose bold flavor and character reflects the spirit and courage of the sailors of the North Atlantic fishing fleet, and is the same passion that drives what we do. The year round Fisherman's line of beer is a tribute to hard work, and a salute to friendships that endure.

New England's Craft Cider. Locally grown. Freshly Pressed. Gluten-Free. Not from Concentrate.
results.name: February's Board Game Night #BGNio9 + Massive Giveaway

Join us as we kick-off our Country Line Dance Lessons for 2016 in Braintree!  Charleene's Country Line Dance Lessons take place Tuesdays in Braintree and Wednesdays in Weymouth and she has a great team helping her teach the classes.  Beginner lessons @ 6-7pm and Advanced lessons @ 7-8pm.  This is a fun way to learn several country line dances with others and get in a nice workout.  You'll then be able to join in the fun when you are out and see other people line dancing.  Cost is $10.

What to Bring/Wear:


~Water (they do not provide drinks and you will get thirsty)

~Cowboy Boots (if you have them), boots or shoes w/ heels; no sneakers!

~Comfy Clothes (remember, you're dancing!)

Please plan to arrive a few minutes early if this is your first time attending.  

Please note I am planning to attend no matter who shows up!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Country Line Dance Lessons in Braintree Kick-Off!

Tuesday, February 9th @ 6-8pm

Sons of Italy

161 King Hill Road, Braintree, MA 02184

Phone #n/a

Website: n/a

Meeting Location: Please meet inside the hall.  Pay and register (if it's your first time) at the welcome table and join us on the dance floor!

Host/Organizer: Angela 

Min/Max: None at this time as I am attending no matter what and the room can accommodate a few dozen people.

Guests: 2 Adults (21+) per Member
Price Range: $10pp for lessons

Cash Only Policy: Please bring cash! Paying for our meals in cash allows us to avoid the confusion of having the waitstaff run multiple credit card slips and generally helps to keep things simpler for everyone.

Cost/Fees:  Cost is $10pp for the lesson.  There are currently no fees associated with this event aside from paying for your food and beverages.  If you want to make your annual voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio.

RSVP Deadline: Tuesday @ 5pm

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: TBD; FYI - This happens weekly and they don't dance if the governor says to stay off the road.

No-Show Policy:  People who RSVP "Yes" to events are expected to exercise common sense and common courtesy. That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events.  Please be advised that any Assistant Organizer (AO) or the Group Organizer (GO) can remove a member from Social Fun who has 3 No-Shows in the past 3 months.  Additionally, Organizers may disallow members with 2 or more "No Show" marks from attending their events.  

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Parking: Free and ample parking on-site.

Directions/Location Overview:  Located near the end of King Hill Road on the right-hand side, King Hill Road is located at the lighted intersection of Pond and Granite Streets.  Luke's Convenience Store is on the corner in the intersection and BASE is being it on the corner of Pond Street.

From Route 93: Take Exit 6/Route 37 heading south towards 5 corners.  At 5 corners bear right staying on Grnaite Street keeping Bertucci's/Panera Bread on your left and Dunkin Donuts on your right.  Follow about 1 mile thru one set of lights.  At next set of lights you will take a right onto King Hill Road.  Follow King Hill Road till you get to the hall on your right.

results.description:
This is an art and music party in Newton Corner for Mardi Gras and Carnival that will be great for socializing and meeting new people, both Meetup and non-Meetup members.  There will be art, music, food, raffle prizes, and dancing.  Great way to celebrate the mid-point of winter and at a really cool upscale restaurant WITH FREE GARAGE PARKING.  It's a fundraiser for the non-profit Unbound Visual Art.  You can come for the entire evening or just part of it.  Tickets in advance are just $10 and $12 at the door.  Ok to bring guests too. Free masks and beads for all!


Get your tickets here: 

http://www.unboundvisualarts.org/mardi-gras-and-carnival-arts-celebration/

Here's a little more information. 

Unbound Visual Arts has started a new tradition in Boston and we want you to be a part of it.  Its an evening of fun and celebration for all Unbound Visual Arts members, guests and friends at the very contemporary Social Restaurant and Bar, 320 Washington Street, Newton Corner.  The restaurant, with free garage parking, is located in the Crowne Plaza Hotel.  We'll have a live Mardi Gras band,  Josiah Reibstein Trio, light hor d' horeauves appropriate for Mardi Gras & Carnival, a full cash bar, an art show of UVA member's work,  dancing, and a raffle as well as a silent auction to win some great prizes.  Come and be part of the excitement. Share a good time with artists and other art supporters from throughout the area. We'll provide the beads and masks too! Free garage parking and its on the 57, 504 and 554 bus lines.

Don't know what Mardi Gras and Carnival is all about? No problem, it's basically a huge world wide celebration that happens every year to start the Spring. It's really a big deal in New Orleans and most Latin American and many European countries. It's also called "Fat Tuesday" because theoretically its the last day to indulge before Lent sets in for Christians.
results.how_to_find_us: Check in at the ticket table
results.name: Art Party for Mardi Gras & Carnival (Fat Tuesday)

CALLING ALL New C&C Members!

                           Tonight is all about YOU

Bring your favorite game and show us how to play it or just come and meet some new people who share your same passion in game playing.

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford .  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play games.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: New Members Night in Medford

results.description:
Please join us and Attorney Melissa Sydney for a special event that will be important for people who want to understand the tax implications of divorce or separation.

It is easy to get caught up in the emotional turmoil of divorce. Property division, custody arrangements, and child support and alimony agreements are all divorce-related matters that carry significant tax implications. Melissa Sydney, a seasoned trust and estates attorney at Burns & Levinson LLP, will walk you through the tax implications of issues relating to property division, custody arrangements, child support and alimony agreements, as well as your individual income tax return. She also will cover common mistakes that people make and how to avoid them.

There is no charge for attendance and complimentary refreshments and light fare will be provided for your enjoyment throughout the event.

Burns & Levinson LLP is a leading Boston-based law firm. Attorney Sydney has extensive experience helping clients with tax-efficient estate planning, multigenerational wealth transfers, business succession planning, charitable planning, gift and income tax planning, nuptial agreements and general probate and estate administration. She was selected to the Massachusetts Rising Stars list [masked]) for Estate & Probate. For more information on Attorney Sydney, please click here:

http://www.burnslev.com/our-attorneys/melissa-sydney

Directions: If you are taking public transportation, 125 Summer Street is located just a few blocks away from both South Station and Downtown Crossing. If you are driving, you can park in the parking garage of 125 Summer Street. Enter the parking garage at 30 Lincoln Street. Bring your parking ticket with you to Burns & Levinson (where you check into the seminar on the 8th floor) and you can pay $10 (cash or check) to receive a voucher for parking.

This is a multi-group event listed on other meetups, so attendance will be greater than the RSVP's shown on this meetup alone.


Contact Deanna Coyle for more information or to RSVP to her directly ([masked];[masked])
results.how_to_find_us: Garage parking is available at 125 Summer Street for a discounted rate of $10. Enter the parking garage at 30 Lincoln Street. Burns & Levinson is located on the 8th floor. Please call\/text Deanna at 508-333-3191 with questions or for directions.
results.name: Tax Implications of Divorce or Separation

results.description:
What: Finnish Lessons 2.0 

What can the World Learn from Educational Change in Finland? 


Where: 

Monroe C. Gutman Library
6 Appian Way, Cambridge, MA
www.gse.harvard.edu/library
Gutman Library Distinguished Author Series

When:

Tuesday, February 9
6-7p.m.
Gutman Conference Center
(refreshments provided)

Who: 


Pasi Sahlberg is a Finnish teacher, teacher educator,
researcher, and policymaker. He has a MSc in
mathematics, a teaching diploma, and a Ph.D. in
education. He has served in various expert and senior
management positions in the Finnish government, the
World Bank in Washington, DC, and The European
Commission in Torino, Italy. 

Learn More about Pasi sahlberg: http://pasisahlberg.com/news/hgse-distinguished-author-series-talk-on-feb-9/

Panel discussion with Boston College Professor Andy Hargreaves, Vermont Secretary of Education and GSE doctoral student Rebecca Holcombe, Ed.M.’90, and Ed.M. IEP candidate Hibatalla Ibrahim.


Why:
He is currently a visiting professor of practice at HGSE.
This book details the complexity of educational change by illustrating Finland’s educational performance in light of the most recent international data and evidence. It shows how systematic focus on teacher and leader professionalism, enhancing trust in teachers, delegating  decision-making on teaching and learning to schools, and investing in equity rather than competition and choice, standardization, test-based accountability and other market-based reform ideas have made Finnish schools successful.
“In the revised edition of his award-winning book, Pasi Sahlberg builds on his vast knowledge of education around the globe. Whether or not you have read Finnish Lessons, you should read and ponder this new edition right away.”
Howard Gardner, John H. and Elisabeth A. Hobbs Professor of Cognition and Education “The story of Finland’s extraordinary educational reforms is one that should inform
policymakers and educators around the world. Teacher professionalism, intelligent accountability, and a systematic focus on equity are among the aspects of Finland’s education system that have inspired others. This updated edition presents these lessons in a vivid and inspiring
style.” Linda Darling-Hammond, Charles E. Ducommun Professor of Education at Stanford University
results.name: Finnish Lessons: What can the World Learn from Educational Change in Finland?

results.description: Hello fellow lovers of Democracy! We're happy to announce the Democracy Den Event Series, held in our Harvard Square office!! Our inaugural event, DEMOCRACY DINNER, is this Tuesday, February 9 from 6-8 pm, and you're invited! It's mardi gras, and we've decided to douse our "democracy blues" with a Democracy Dinner! We'll serve up a light meal and delicious pies, and discuss the mass movement called Democracy Spring, coming in April. This march from Philly to DC with culminate in sit-ins, rallies and meetings with our elected officials to demand people power over the power of money in politics. Americans want to know- how can we address climate change, racial iniquity and a staggering income gap, among other pressing issues? Let's get at the root of these crises and address the "mother of all issues"- Democracy! We'll discuss Democracy Spring and surrounding events, and also how our organization, Small Planet Institute, can serve as a hub for democratic engagment in our own neighborhood. We're thinking movie screenings, book discussions, trainings and social gatherings to come together as a population with people power! Join us for our first event to learn, share, discuss, get inspired, and get moving!
results.name: Democracy Dinner (eat pie and learn about Democracy Spring)

Tuesday, February 9th @ 6-8pm

Sons of Italy

161 King Hill Road, Braintree, MA 02184

That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events. results.description:
When it comes to Enterprise level sales, the way you prospect changes. But what exactly is different and what is the best approach to connecting to larger companies?

Liz Cain, Senior Director, WW Business Development at NetSuite, will share how NetSuite approaches prospecting and the unique challenges of building credibility and relationships when involved in complex B2B sales.


About Our Speaker

Liz Cain is the Senior Director of Global Business Development at NetSuite (NYSE:N), the industry’s leading provider of cloud-based financials / ERP and omnichannel commerce software suites. Liz founded NetSuite’s Business Development program with dual goals – first, to accelerate lead generation for the Direct sales team and second, to build a pipeline of talent to promote into NetSuite’s sales organization.

Liz’s team is responsible recruiting, hiring, and onboarding regular classes of Business Development Representatives and Solution Consulting Associates (pre-sales), and managing the daily operations of the BDR/SCA programs including inbound lead qualification, outbound prospecting, the development and administration of product, sales, business and industry training.

The American Association of Inside Sales Professionals selected Liz as the “Spirit Award” winner for her enthusiasm and advocacy for advancing the profession of inside sales. Liz graduated from Middlebury College with a BS in Economics.
results.name: Enterprise Prospecting Techniques w/ Liz Cain of NetSuite

results.description:
**********************************

Agenda:

**********************************

David Booth: Introduction to Semantic Web Technology

This month we will start with the basics and provide an introduction to Semantic Web technology, including RDF, Turtle, OWL and SPARQL queries.  If you've heard of these things but weren't entirely sure of what they are, how to use them, or what they're good for, this is a golden opportunity to have your curiosity satisfied and your questions answered. 


We will use slides from Ivan Herman's Lisbon tutorial:
http://www.w3.org/2013/Talks/0902-Lisbon-IH/Talk.pdf


About the speaker

David Booth is a co-organizer of the monthly Cambridge Semantic Web meetup.  He is a senior software architect and has been involved with Semantic Web technology for over 10 years.  In the past 5 years he has focused on applying this technology to problems in healthcare and life sciences at the Cleveland Clinic, PanGenX, KnowMED, pharma companies, and on a DoD-funded data migration project that uses RDF and related Semantic Web technology to achieve interoperability of diverse healthcare information.  He was a W3C Fellow[masked], worked at HP Software and at AT&T Bell Labs, and holds a PhD in Computer Science from UCLA.
results.how_to_find_us: Rm 32-D463, 4th floor, Star Conference Room, Stata Center, MIT
results.name: Cambridge Semantic Web Monthly Meetup: Introduction to Semantic Web Technology

results.description:
Our next journal club will be on… Truffles!!

We will read a publication by Splivallo et al showing the involvement of microbes in synthesizing the delicious truffle aromas. Why reading about that? Because this study will be the starting point of our next DIYbio project at BosLab, starting on February 20.

By going through this paper, we’ll take the opportunity to speak about experiment design, and microbe identification using 16s ribosomal RNA sequencing.

You can download the pdf of the publication here:
http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1462-2920.12521/full

The agenda for the journal club:
- Short overview of the paper to understand the scope of this work.
- Go over the paper figure by figure. So everyone understand what exactly what was done and how it was done.
- Free form discussion.

Previous reading of the paper is not required but much advised. It will help you not to get lost. As well some prior knowledge of basic biological concepts will be very useful for you to follow: what are genes, the central dogma of DNA -> RNA -> Proteins, and some general understanding of how viruses infect cells.

See you all soon!
The Boslab team

Location:
The journal club is taking place at 500 Technology Square Cambridge, room 189 (to the left from the main entrance). It is a big building behind A4 restaurant. The doors are automatically locked some time after 6:30PM. If you are lost or got late call (256)[masked], someone will let you in.
results.name: Journal Club: Truffles

***This meetup is restricted to people who have attended three or more of our discussion meetups in the prior six months, including one Accountability Session.  See details below for more.***

Would you like to help organize meetups for the Knapsack group?  Here's a great opportunity to get involved and help set the schedule for the spring.  Bring your plan for a meetup and we'll work with you to make it happen!  If you're bringing a plan, please include a full description for posting, some options for dates, and what you need for support.


We'll also be planning our next Community Meeting, and your input will be helpful for making this a big and successful event.


People who attend would be eligible to become organizers.  You will learn more about the expectations for organizers when you come.

Note: if you have not met the requirement of attending three or more of our discussion meetups in the six months prior to this meetup, including one Accountability Session, you are welcome to add your ideas for meetups or the Community Meeting in the comments area, or share with an organizer.  We hope you will attend more things in the coming months!

Accessibility Information: Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The fourth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.

Note: We welcome intrepid winter bike riders, though there are not many good spots for parking bikes, and bicycles are prohibited in the building.  We apologize for the inconvenience.

results.description:
Presentation: A focus and technical conversation on information security and AWS. We'll discuss best practices and case studies. This is for anyone with an interest in securing cloud infrastructures and implementing security best practices.

More Details:

• The importance of cybersecurity and specific tactics that cloud solution architects should incorporate, like; boundary protection, system hardening through DISA STIG’s, patch management, continuous monitoring, and Identity & Access Management using AWS tools.

• Highlight critical market trends around cybersecurity liability and some of the common mistakes organizations make while configuring and setting AWS VPC’s.


• Implementing security through Automation where automation templates are used for environments that incorporate best practices.

Presenting is Gaurav "GP" Pal, Cloud-Broker Platforms Architect and Cloud Solutions Strategist for Public Sector, Non-Profit and Commercial Customers. Principle, stackArmor, a member company of the AWS Partner Network. More about GP here: https://www.linkedin.com/in/gppal

Thank you to Glenn Donovan, Business Development with stackArmor for making the arrangements, sponsoring food/presentation, and bringing us together with WeWork who is hosting our location.

Location: WeWork's South Station location, 745 ATLANTIC AVE, BOSTON, MA 02111
https://www.wework.com/locations/boston/south-station

Thank you.

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Date: Tuesday, February 9, 6:30 PM

Location: Microsoft office, Cambridge Center, Cambridge, MA.  Use the Microsoft-specific building entrance.

Cost: Free and includes pizza!

Reservations and Photo ID: Required. Reserve here at Meetup or by sending an email to [masked].  We require your full name for building security purposes, so please include that if your Meetup username does not provide it or you will NOT be added to the security list.  Please also bring a photo ID to present to building security upon entering the building.

Topic:
"Passwords: Keys to the Kingdom," presented by Patrick Hynds of  DTS."

Description:
In this presentation, Patrick Hynds of DTS will talk about the aspects of passwords that most people don’t know or even think about.  These include best practices, password attack vectors and ways to make passwords more manageable.  This presentation is the basis for a PluralSight Course about to be released on this subject.

Patrick is an expert on Microsoft technology and experienced with other technologies as well from storage systems to firewalls. Patrick has taught software development as well as Network Architecture and regularly takes on the role of consultant in which he enjoys mastering difficult troubleshooting assignments. A 1988 graduate of West Point and a Gulf War veteran, Patrick brings an uncommon level of dedication to his leadership role at DTS. He is experienced in addressing business challenges with special emphasis on security issues involving leading-edge database, storage, web and hardware systems. Patrick often speaks at major technical conferences.

Early bird tickets cost $15 until January 30! RSVP on Eventbrite!

Our weekly work session will be at the Cambridge Innovation Center in Kendall Square, on the FOURTH FLOOR, in the CAFE. These Hack Nights are our time to meet in person to work on and discuss civic tech projects. Come by to say hi and hack with us!

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

Schedule
7:00pm - Opening remarks, project updates, announcements
7:20pm - New member orientation
8:00pm - Hacking!

During the event, join our Hackpad for announcement links and collaborative note taking.

To ensure that Code for Boston is a welcoming space for all, staff and participants are held to our Code of Conduct.

Since we all know how Boston transportation works in the snow (it doesn't), we'll be postponing the "Mistborn" meeting to tomorrow - Tuesday, Feb. 9.

If you have comments or anything you wanted especially to bring up for discussion, please send me an email and I'll make sure it gets read at the meeting (you can include your book vote as well, if you like).

Sorry for the inconvenience, everyone - hopefully the weather will be cooperative by March!

*Update 1/16/16: I think we're gonna do the Pret A Manger near State Street station for this month. We used this as our emergency location in January. This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Please join us!

Tuesday, February 9
7:30 PM, Fox Library Community Room
eBird in 2016: Past, present, and future
eBird was founded in 2002 and began to be widely used by birders in 2005. It has since expanded globally, provided free data access to scientists and conservationists worldwide, amassed a user community of 200,000 users and will cross 300 million observations. In 2015 eBird launched its own mobile data entry apps for iPhone and Android and integrated with the Macaulay Library to create a 21st Century digital museum of photos and sounds, all of which can be easily added right through your eBird checklists. eBird also has united a global community of birders by being fully multi-lingual and having specific versions worldwide, despite having completely integrated data working behind the scenes in whatever language. May 2015 saw the first ever Global Big Day, a cooperative effort by birders worldwide to take a snapshot of birdlife worldwide, engaging over 40,000 birders who recorded 6000+ species in the process. With 2016 poised to be eBird's best year ever, this presentation will discuss what eBird offers today and how it hopes to continue to unite birders worldwide in the common cause of creating the best and most complete biodiversity database in existence and get it into the hands of those who need it most. Marshall Iliff is one of four eBird Project Leaders.
results.name: Meeting: eBird in 2016: Past, present, and future presented by Marshall Iliff

results.description:
Though we might wish we could, we can't always think of everything ourselves. Join Danny and other writers for a chance to engage your writing with a community and get the kind of new, original feedback that gets the writing juices flowing. Before every meeting we'll each submit a short story, section of a novel or other work to be reviewed (up to 10-12 double spaced pages or[masked] words*). Come prepared to give written and verbal feedback on others' work as well as receive feedback on your own. Open to all, but limited to 5 each session (plus organizers) on a first come first serve basis.

Please RSVP and be prepared to submit your work about a week before we meet to give everyone a chance to read. RSVPs will close a few days before the event.

Submissions are hosted on a shared Box.com folder, which requires an email address to access.  If this is your first time joining, let Danny know your preferred email address and he will invite you.

Monthly
Cost is $15

Led by Danny Shain

Danny graduated from Union College with a degree in English, and has spent years working as a copy-editor, freelance writer and blogger.  A follower of technology trends whose reading interests range from the fantastical to the contemporary to the philosophical, Danny is excited to help people refine their writing, express themselves, and build a writing community through this workshop.

*Note: If you'd like to include slightly more than 10-12 pages to provide some context (ie: your chapter ends 1-2 pages later) that's ok, but please indicate which pages you'd like critiqued. Pages beyond that should be submitted as an optional read.

If we meet, we'll do a compassion meditation, a 20-minute meditation in which we bring to mind someone's suffering on the in-breath, and evoke compassion on the out-breath. The object of compassion may be someone else or yourself. 

This meditation in Chapter Three of the book, Secular Meditation, and is a secular adaptation of the Tibetan practice of Tonglen

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonglen We'll have a discussion after the meditation.

This is not the same as a loving-kindness meditation, but builds on the practice of loving-kindness.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
Join Us on Ash Wednesday and Throughout Lent

The Basilica welcomes and invites you to join us throughout Lent, as we are reminded of the Paschal Mystery in Jesus' suffering, death and resurrection. During this season of preparation, Lent helps to deepen our faith by individual and common acts of prayer, fasting and sacrifice. 

Wednesday, February 10, 2016 is Ash Wednesday

Ashes will be distributed at all Masses:

7:00 am, 12:10 pm, 5:00 pm, and 7:00 pm (Spanish)

All Masses will be in the main church. 
Due to Ash Wednesday, the Novena to Our Lady of Perpetual Help will be abbreviated to include the prayers and general blessing of the icon after communion.

Catholics between the ages of 18 and 59 are obliged to fast on Ash Wednesday and GoodFriday. 

In addition, all Catholics 14 years old and older must abstain from meat on Ash Wednesday, Good Friday, and all the Fridays of Lent.

Fasting means the partaking of only one full meal. Some food (not equaling another full meal) is permitted at breakfast and around midday or in the evening-depending on when a person chooses to eat the main or full meal. 

<a>https://ci6.googleusercontent.com/proxy/NX0ny3GO6sF0ecbmpTBvL5moLVenbhzOdVTnTfGcgFoIstXHv8WxY4GleS-gxDQRryq4uyz8TAGifIxiTQWWLGq79sj_AKzflGq0dPpB6owg90cuL5SZr55ZPvjCgBl4mPGK=s0-d-e1-ft#http://files.ctctcdn.com/ac387da8301/3fa5e79c-dfb2-409e-a4a0-ba0caad98658.png</a>; Lent Schedule


Mass, Reconciliation, Stations of the Cross

Prayer and penance are central throughout Lent, the Basilica offers opportunities to visit and pray silently or through participation in daily Mass. A complete schedule of services has been posted on our website.

<a>View Schedule >> </a>

With the spring market upon us, we will be discussing recent economic trends in the real estate market and the real estate economy as a whole. Specific topics will include:

1. The state of the real estate market over the past year
2. Our opinion as to what this upcoming spring market will be like and the remainder of the 2016 season
3. Where we see prices headed over the next year and beyond

results.description:
Join us for a Weekday Morning Breakfast at a popular local breakfast spot in Braintree Square: Kristin's!  Kristin's is known for their varied and diverse menu including several different kinds of flavored pancakes from Boston Cream Pie to Fluffernutter, Banana Bread French Toast & "Loaded" Homefries (all of which I have enjoyed).  They have a well-rounded Early Bird Special for $3.99 which ends at 9am weekdays.  Most items are under $8 so this is definitely an affordable place to eat.  Please check out their website for their "regular" menu and the 3 minute clip from The Phantom Gourmet.

Many people enjoy going out to eat for breakfast but we are limited on when we are able to do so due to having to actually go to work 5 day a week.  Let's throw that out the window and see who's around weekday mornings to join us for breakfast!  This will be a great way to meet and get to know some fellow group members over delicious breakfast food in a friendly neighborhood breakfast spot in Braintree.

Most breakfast restaurants do not take reservations but I am usually able to call ahead the morning of the event to give the restaurant a heads-up and set aside some tables for us but we may have to wait a few minutes to be seated. Seating may be tight/cramped, we may have to wait for a table even if we call ahead, and we may not be able to save a seat for late arrivals.  Additionally, true to SSDOMG tradition, most breakfast restaurant are a cash-only establishment.  Yup, no credit cards accepted.  So, be sure to bring cash or your ATM card (they probably have one in the lobby for you to withdraw some cash or there's a bank across the street) as well as your breakfast appetite as we enjoy a nice casual Sunday morning breakfast with new and familiar diners!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Weekday Breakfast!

Wednesday, February 10th @ 8:15am

Kristin's 

349 Washington Street

Braintree (Square), MA 02184

[masked]

Website:  www.kristinsbreakfast.com

Meeting Location: Just inside the front door or Our Table(s) after we are seated.

Event Host(s)/Organizer(s): Angela

Min/Max: Minimum of 4 people 72 hours prior to the event.  Maximum of 8 members.  This may increase depending on interest and restaurant.  Our WaitList (WL) has been set to Automatic which means members a spot opens up in the order in which you RSVPed.  This means if you are on the WL and you can no longer attend you need to change your RSVP.

Guests: 1 adult per member

Price Range: Most meals range from $5-$15.  Yelp shows this as under $10. 


Cash Only Policy: Please bring cash! Paying for all of our meals in cash has been SSDOMG'S policy for over seven years. It allows us to avoid the confusion of having the waitstaff run multiple credit card slips and generally helps to keep things simpler for everyone.  Most breakfast restaurants only accept cash.

Event Fees: Event fees are $2pp.  These are collected towards the end of the event, generally when the bill arrives.

2016 Annual Membership: Annual Membership dues for 2016 are $5.00 per year. These are collected towards the end of the event, generally when the bill arrives.

RSVP Deadline: 1 hour prior to the event @ 7:15am ~ Any changes may not be seen after that time and no new RSVPs will be allowed after this time (which is an hour prior to the event).

Snow/Inclement Weather Date: None at this time.  We're not letting the snow stop us.

Late Arrivals: While late arrivals are generally OK, for this event if you are more than 5 minutes late and they have a table ready for those in attendance we may not be able to save a seat for you. Conversely, we may be waiting 10 minutes before we are seated.  I do plan to arrive my usual 5-10 minutes early.

No-Show Policy: We have updated and greatly simplified our no-show policy. People who RSVP "Yes" to events are expected to exercise common sense and common courtesy. That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events.

Failure to do the above may result in your removal from the group at the Group Organizer's discretion. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Parking: In addition to on-street parking, there is a Municipal Parking lot about 300 feet south of the restaurant next to Dependable Cleaners across from the gas station.  There's other business lots nearby which you can utilize as well.

Directions: Located in the heart of "Braintree Square" right near the intersection of Washington, Storrs, and Elm Streets, Kristin's is nestled in a row of storefronts between Pura Vida Salon and GLOW.   Nearby businesses include the VFW (diagonally across to the south), Dunkin Donuts (about 6 doors down en route to the Municipal Parking lot), and Spa by Nancy (across the street on the opposite side of Storrs Ave, directly in front of you at the light on Elm Street).

results.description:
Register http://bit.ly/1nOu3uN

In an age where we find ourselves being bombarded with all kinds of information from all different directions, never has the need for simple explanations been so pressing.

We now live in an always-on and always-connected world. This has not only changed the way we see and hear things but also the way we learn.

As a result, the units in which we now deliver explanations have to be far shorter and much more to the point. But getting this right and finding the balance between an explanation that is simple yet also engaging is not always easy.

So you can become an expert explainer, we’ve created the 5 Simple Rules of Explanation.

At the end of this session, you will:

-Recognize the value of simple explanations.

-Become an expert explainer.

-Learn how to effectively communicate through the use of videos.

http://i0.wp.com/wcc.on24.com/event/11/19/10/5/rt/1/images/speakerbiowidgetimage1452543210773/paul_sq.jpg?w=605

SpeakerPaul Meyer 
Director of North and South America 
simpleshow USA corp.

Paul Meyer is the Director of Simpleshow North and South America. Simpleshow is the market leader in explainer videos. Everyday they help their customers such as Adobe, Microsoft, BMW, McDonalds, Porsche, VW, J&J, BASF, SAP, Bayer, Novartis, AON, ebay, Hershey’s, Red Bull and Audi explain their training, product or marketing ideas through the production of simple, concise, interactive videos.

Paul has over 20 years of digital marketing experience that he now brings to the training and learning world. He was the Director of Digital Operations for Televisa and their joint partnership with Hearst, overseeing their websites of National Geographic, Men’s Health, Cosmopolitan, Harper’s Bazaar, and Esquire magazines. These sites had more than 35 million unique monthly visitors. He also honed his digital skills working with Banco Santander and Telefonica, two of the world’s largest banks and telecommunications companies.

Simpleshow was awarded the international Davey Awards for Online Video 2015, Deauville Green Award in 2015, Online Communicator Award 2015, Spark Award for Media Excellence 2014 and the European Lovie Award in 2013.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Product Leaders are constantly learning!

1. Check out upcoming free webinars for online learning at Webcast Digest

2. Browse the Product Excellence Book Store 

Brought to you by SUPA Product Academy
results.name: Webcast: Keep It Simple! 5 Rules to Become an Expert Explainer

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street 
Mission Hill, Roxbury 
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops) 
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2). 

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).


We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm or so (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Use the T - #66 bus comes by - E-Line or Orange Line

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!
Looking for Gifted Marketers to
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

Question:

This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:

For this operation, there are "No qualifications - no limits!"

Thanks to the efficiency and BI (business intelligence) of Fair Foods of Dorchester (FairFoods.org), founded about 35 years ago by self-reported vegetarian Nancy Jamison, we have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread). 

That's why I post it on a meetup like this (not merely on a volunteer meetup).

There are tens of thousands of college students who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases.
There are tens of thousands (myriads) of homemakers and working individuals who could benefit by saving some money on their weekly produce purchases.
Lots and lots of seniors AND needy folks, and there's no operational shame in prudent fiscal management if you know that you can get quality produce at a far lower price.

[The snag is that, unlike in grocery stores - or even in Haymarket, your variety of produce is severely limited here because you're getting what Fair Foods sends to any specific site; you are unable to select from a broader arrangement of vegetables and a broader arrangement of fruits.  Typically, you get about 7-11 different items - about 5-8 different vegetables and 2-3 fruits, and you're often 'gifted' with extra items - 30 ounce jug of fresh hummus or lentil salad or chickpea salads, pound of garlic, large one-lb plastic container of ground pepper, or lots of other 'big items' we don't typically buy.]

Make us busy - very busy.

DATE: Wednesday, February 10, 2016

TIME: Registration opens up at 6:30pm | Screening begins at 7:00pm LOCATION: AMC Boston Common | 175 Tremont St. | Boston, MA

Just in time for election season, America's favorite political provocateur, Michael Moore, is back with his new film, WHERE TO INVADE NEXT. Honored by festivals and critics' groups alike, WHERE TO INVADE NEXT is an expansive, hilarious, and subversive comedy in which the Academy Award®-winning director confronts the most pressing issues facing America today and finds solutions in the most unlikely places. The creator of FAHRENHEIT 9/11 and BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE has returned with an epic movie that's unlike anything he has done before—an eye-opening call to arms to capture the American Dream and restore it in, of all places, America.

Following the screening there will be a Q&A with David Filipov, Boston Globe Reporter and former Moscow Bureau Chief, moderated by Janice Page, Boston Globe Film Editor.

Are you overseeing or taking care of others in your family, community or neighborhood? Do you feel overwhelmed or stressed by the conflicting demands from your role as a working or employed daughter, son or friend caring for your parent, relative, longtime family friend, neighbor or spouse? Do you sometimes feel like you need more confidence and skills in how best to do this? Do you need more practical tips, information, skill demos, guidance or help but do not qualify for public support and don't also have adequate means to pay private providers for ongoing one-on-one guidance and help with your sick or aging relative? Do you feel left out of the available private and public support systems? Do you feel like you need to connect and interact more with people facing similar circumstances? Do you sometimes ask yourself who is taking care of you? Have you ever considered that by taking the time to take better care of yourself, you will have more to give? Do you ever wonder how others are doing it? You are not alone. Come meet, join, have fun, shape and benefit from the activities of this group with other wonderful, caring individuals.


Looking forward to meeting you all,

Rose, Organizer

results.description:
Boston Traders' Meetup

You are invited to attend the monthly Boston Traders' Meetup meetings.

The format for the monthly meetings is that each person will introduce her- or himself and state the market that he or she trades and perhaps a very brief description of the approach taken. For example, an introduction could be, "Hi, my name is Fred Hampton and I trade forex breakouts during the London session."

From there, the floor is open for people to discuss anything about trading. You may talk about something you learned recently about trading or about an obstacle that you are facing in trading or make a request for resources from other members.

Please print out and bring this BostonTradersMeetup sign so you can connect with the other members easily.
www.meetup.com/BostonTraders/files/

Part of the purpose of this group is for people to connect with other traders so it's encouraged for people to exchange contact info. For example, if you are an options trader and another options trader talks about a topic that interests you, then feel free to ask the person if she or he would like to exchange contact info.

--------------------


This meeting is located in the Starbucks inside what is called the "Boston Marriott" even though the hotel is located in Kendall Square, Cambridge. The Kendall Square subway stop is a Red Line stop at "Kendall."

This meeting is FREE and it repeats on the 2nd Wednesday of every month.
results.name: Boston Traders' Meetup Group Meeting 2nd Wednesday at 6 PM in Cambridge

Hope to see you next Wednesday!


Doing Agile at Scale 

Speaker:  Stan Wrobel

Meeting Date:  Wednesday February 10 , 2016

Meeting Time: Networking 6-6:30pm           Discussion 6:30-8pm

Location:    Oracle             

45 Network Drive Northwest Park                   

Burlington MA 01803

Cost:          Free! 

Abstract:

Your SCRUM team is humming along creating value for your customers and increasing its team velocity with every sprint.  What do you do, though, after adding a second team, or a third, or a fourth?  Taking Agile to the next level is a challenge that may be even greater than the challenge of adopting SCRUM in the first place.  Do you go right to a Scrum of Scrums?  Do you schedule more and bigger meetings?  How would you do Agile for portfolio or program management?  Turns out, there are many options available, but which do you choose?  Stan Wrobel helps you navigate this landscape drawing on experience with large IT organizations and the Scaled Agile Framework.  Create value for your customers at an even greater pace than before!

Speaker Biography: 

With over 30 years in the computer industry, Stan has served in a variety of roles, including Business Analyst, Developer, Tester and manager of software quality teams.  Starting out in the Computer-Aided-Manufacturing industry in the 1970's, Stan has branched out into new areas such as fault-tolerant transaction processing, commercial websites and Air Traffic Management until finally settling in at the Massachusetts Executive Office of Education, where he leads a team of testers deployed to multiple sprint teams.  Stan is a certified Project Management Professional and SCRUM Master who has been educating himself in both SCRUM and the Scaled Agile Framework as his organization continues on the transition from a classic PMO to an Agile/SCRUM development organization.

results.description:
6 - 6:30 PM - Networking


6:30 - 8 PM - Presentation and Q&A

Title & Abstract:

Text analysis with R, Python, and Spark, using the State of the Union Address and Congressional Hearings

Frank D. Evans, data scientist at Exaptive, provides a conceptual and technical look at text analysis on big data with open source tools. His fodder is 70 years of State of the Union Addresses, from Truman to Obama, and 20 years of Congressional hearing transcripts. Using R, he performs text clustering to identify trends. Using Python, he goes a step further to create topic models that identify commonalities and differences between presidencies. Then combining Python with Spark, he topic models a data set 2500 times as big. He’ll explain the statistics methods behind each analysis and show how he implemented them in code. He’ll also explain how to produce plots or even some live data applications to let others explore the modeled data.

About Speaker:

Frank D. Evans (@frankdevans) is a data scientist with an expertise in Big Data, especially text analysis. His work spans financial, behavioral, and political analytics. Frank recently gave a TEDx talk on how data science can fix gerrymandering.
results.name: Text analysis with R, Python and Spark

Stéphane joined Moderna in the summer of 2011 when it was a one employee company. He has assembled a world-class team and raised more than $1Billion between equity financing and upfront from licensing collaborations.

He was previously CEO of bioMérieux, a world leader in the diagnostics industry. bioMerieux has more than 6,000 employees, a market capitalization of €2.5 billion, and sales of more than €1.3 billion.

Prior to his time at bioMérieux, Stéphane was the managing director of Eli Lilly Belgium and executive director of global manufacturing strategy and supply chain at Eli Lilly in Indianapolis, Indiana. He started at Lilly in their UK manufacturing plant outside London.

results.description:
High-end storage is expensive, and SQL Server data compression can make your database smaller. So lets compress all the tables! No--unfortunately, it's not that easy. We'll talk about how data compression actually works, and the differences between ROW and PAGE compression. As part of this, we'll look at the costs and benefits associated with each type of compression. By the end of this session, you'll have a better idea of when compression is the right solution, as well as what type of compression to use.

Andy Mallon (@amtwo) is a SQL Server DBA that has managed databases in the healthcare, finance, e-commerce, and non-profit sectors. He has over 12 years of experience supporting high-volume, highly-available OLTP environments with demanding performance needs. Andy blogs at www.am2.co, is co-organizer of SQL Saturday Boston.


Lighting talk "Ownership Chaining" by Michael Kane.

Meeting Sponsored By: First Pro, Inc
results.name: Data Compression -- How does it work, and is it right for you? - Andy Mallon

Michele Grzenda (AMC Boston Young Members & Hiking/Backpacking Trip leader) will share her experience as a participant on a 2 week guided tour of Eastern China. Highlights include visiting 7 UNESCO sites including the Great Wall, Forbidden City, Summer Palace, and Terra-cotta Warrior Museum. During a 5-day cruise down the Yangtze River, Michele's presentation will include side trips to Three Gorges Dam - the world's largest hydroelectricity project; Jingzhou, a city located on the banks of the Yangtze River with 6000 years history, and Shibaozhai, literally "Precious Stone Fortress" is a hill along the bank of the Yangtze River. Photos and stories from Beijing, Chongqing, and Shanghai will inspire you to plan a trip there. Michele will share travel tips on how to find bargain guided trips!

Homemade dishes are welcome, store bought goodies & takeout are equally welcome. Plates, bowls, cups, cutlery, napkins and drink pitchers will be supplied. The auditorium has a kitchen if you need to do any re-warming or prep (stovetop, oven, microwave, sink & fridge). Please bring your own cooking pots if needed for stovetop. Potlucks start at 6:30pm.

Walk through the Boston Common uphill towards the State House on Beacon St. To the left of the State House is Joy St; follow Joy St uphill to the AMC Auditorium Building (brownstone), #4 Joy St on the left hand side of the road.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
