results.description:
Have you been taught to micro-manage your time and yet it seems you never have enough of it?  Drawing on Christine Duvivier’s professional and academic work, this webinar leads you out of turmoil and into a more effective model, so you can avoid three major obstacles cited by executives.  Discover positive change tools that free you to be happier, have more energy, and engage your team to reach new heights, as you learn the limits of time management and how to achieve greater impact with greater ease. 

Are you a leader or aspiring leader?  Would you like to make a bigger impact, get promoted and make more money without burn out or family sacrifice?


What you come away with:

• Learn small changes that make a big difference

• Understand how to achieve your goals, without sacrificing your life

• Know the power of building from the positive

• Understand why positive thinking isn’t enough—and what to do instead

• Engage others to new levels of commitment that give you relief

• Learn simple ways to boost creativity, resourcefulness, and results

We will use experiential exercises, case studies, Christine's personal experience, and research to share high-impact strategies you can use to get more than you have been taught to expect in your career and life.


Our Leader This Evening

Christine Duvivier, a Master of Positive Psychology, is a leader in the red-hot field of positive psychology. Christine believes that within each of us lie tremendous untapped reservoirs of potential. Discovering  the strategies and power of positive change and, conversely, releasing what holds us back, has been the defining journey of her life and work.


Today, drawing on Christine's 20 + years of mentoring business executives, parents, and leaders from around the world, along with her research in positive psychology, she guides people to unleash the best within—no matter where they stand currently. Learn about what Christine calls, The Gifts that Conflict with School (and are well-suited to leadership and success). 

She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands of individuals and groups worldwide, including Fortune 50 executives, individuals, families, and communities. Author of "What I'd Say if You Wouldn't Roll Your Eyes... love notes to my child," Christine mentors and facilitates other professionals-- including leaders, physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors-- using positive approaches to bring out the full potential in themselves and others.


Clients say, "Christine helped me become the leader I am... get promoted.... turn problem staff to top performers... engage my team....  get people on board with new strategy and culture.... transform my relationships... see the best in me....feel energized."

She has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17. As a mid-level employee in a 135,000- person company, she discovered how to have much greater impact, in much less time, as she followed her own vision, which was contrary to everything around her.  As a result, Christine led a team that convinced the executive committee to adopt a radical new goal, went on to engage employees worldwide in a change that boosted customer loyalty 20%, and was promoted to Worldwide Director of Customer Quality and Loyalty.


While studying and working with Martin Seligman, David Cooperrider, George Vaillant  and other founders in the science of positive psychology & well-being, she experienced the power of positive change when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience. Her groundbreaking research at UPenn identified paths to unleash hidden gifts and lead each of us to thrive in life.


Watch a video interview with Christine, read one of Christine's studies or listen to an audio interview andlearn more on www.christineduvivier.com
results.how_to_find_us: This is a Free webinar- Register Here for the links and dial-in information: http://www.christineduvivier.com/register-have-more-impact-in-less-time-webinar/
results.name: Christine Duvivier: Have More Impact in Less Time

results.description:
Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

results.description:
Feb 10: Our Robots, Ourselves
Contemporary Science Issues and Innovations
Wednesday, February 10, 2015 at 6:30 PM
Belmont Media Center, 9 Lexington St, Belmont MA

Mindell-2014_120x120.jpgDavid A. Mindell, Ph.D., Dibner Professor of the History of Engineering and Manufacturing, and Professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; founder and director of MIT's "DeepArch" research group in technology, archaeology, and the deep sea.

Dr. Mindell's comprehensive research reflects his unusually broad academic background in both engineering and the humanities. His technical work includes theories of engineering systems as well as pioneering technical innovations in engineering and deep ocean robotic archaeology. He has combined his many engineering achievements with historical analyses: the history of engineering, the history of automation in the military, the history of electronics and computing, and the history of space exploration.

Dr. Mindell examines our relationship with robots. How truly independent are they presently, and how autonomous can they be in the future? In the robots we use for space exploration, deep-sea research, and many other tasks. The real "brain" seems to be human, not robotic, His recent book, which he discusses, explains both the value of robots and the actual limits of robotic autonomy at a time when there is increasing controversy about the capabilities of robots.

Dr. Mindell has shared his unique perspective in several books for the general public, most recently Our Robots, Ourselves: Robotics and the Myths of Autonomy (2015). BK_Digital-Apollo_Mindell_110x142.jpg His book War, Technology, and Experience aboard the USS Monitor (2000) won the Sally Hacker Prize from the Society for the History of Technology. This was followed by Between Human and Machine: Feedback, Control, and Computing before Cybernetics in 2002. His third book, Digital Apollo: Human and Machine in the First Six Lunar Landings (2008) was awarded the Emme award for astronautical literature by the American Astronautical Society.
results.name: Our Robots, Ourselves - Contemporary Science Issues and Innovations

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!                                              


To the left there is a chip-in feature. Your donations will go directly to the monthly dues and will allow MAC meetup group to keep going. Any amount would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs
results.name: Climbing at Central Rock (Watertown)

results.description:
Driving's End will present our audience with our driverless future as seen through some of the finest engineers working on these challenges here in the local area.


Launching of Humans Against Driving Non-Profit

This event will be the launch of Humans Against Driving, a non-profit advocacy organization currently being developed and looking for volunteers to help create workable frameworks to regulate driverless cars on the road and ensure security and privacy remain paramount.

Think you would make a good driverless car advocate?  Email [masked].

Want to Speak?

If you're interested in speaking, please email [masked] with the Title "Speaking at Driving's End".  We would love to have a variety of software focused speakers from the driverless space, but we are willing to hear of other focus areas as well.    

Want to sponsor the venue?

If you're interested in sponsoring the venue for this event, please let us know.  We are looking for a space that can hold at least 200 software engineers for 2.5 hours.  Just email [masked].  

Want to sponsor the event?  

Think you would be interesting in sponsoring the event with Pizza, drinks, or other swag?  Feel free to email us with your sponsorship ideas at [masked] and we will get back with you quickly.  

Disclaimer

Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at our local Boston Software Engineers community events do not necessarily express the opinion or views of the Software BASE organization and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors/employers at our local events. 

Software BASE is Growing

Software BASE's Boston chapter has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that Boston Software Engineers is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with job fairs, code labs, meetups, conferences, networking parties, and innovative events on emerging technologies.  We couldn't do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.

This month we'll discuss CSS specificity, which can quickly become an arms race, but where does it end? Check out how bad things can get if you never clean up your code and learn how to avoid project-wide chaos. This session will include a talk and an adventure!

Doors open at 6:30pm for food and drinks, which will be provided by Vermonster. The talk will start at 7pm.

A bit about our presenters:

Francisco Dias (https://twitter.com/ffrandias) is a design engineer at HubSpot and could probably fill this out better with an infographic.

Cris Necochea (https://twitter.com/knick44) likes thinking about big picture issues around markup, accessibility and style in the context of larger engineering teams. He works at HubSpot as a design engineer.

Today, drawing on Christine's 20 + years of mentoring business executives, parents, and leaders from around the world, along with her research in positive psychology, she guides people to unleash the best within—no matter where they stand currently. Learn about what Christine calls, The Gifts that Conflict with School (and are well-suited to leadership and success).


She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands of individuals and groups worldwide, including Fortune 50 executives, individuals, families, and communities. Author of "What I'd Say if You Wouldn't Roll Your Eyes... love notes to my child," Christine mentors and facilitates other professionals-- including leaders, physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors-- using positive approaches to bring out the full potential in themselves and others.

Clients say, "Christine helped me become the leader I am... get promoted.... turn problem staff to top performers... engage my team.... get people on board with new strategy and culture.... transform my relationships... see the best in me....feel energized."

She has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17. As a mid-level employee in a 135,000- person company, she discovered how to have much greater impact, in much less time, as she followed her own vision, which was contrary to everything around her. As a result, Christine led a team that convinced the executive committee to adopt a radical new goal, went on to engage employees worldwide in a change that boosted customer loyalty 20%, and was promoted to Worldwide Director of Customer Quality and Loyalty.

While studying and working with Martin Seligman, David Cooperrider, George Vaillant and other founders in the science of positive psychology & well-being, she experienced the power of positive change when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience. Her groundbreaking research at UPenn identified paths to unleash hidden gifts and lead each of us to thrive in life.

Watch a video interview with Christine, read one of Christine's studies or listen to an audio interview and learn more on www.christineduvivier.com

Register Here
results.how_to_find_us: Register Here: http://www.christineduvivier.com/register-have-more-impact-in-less-time-webinar/

results.description:
Several folks are interested in playing w/ an FPGA design. I think that would be good fun and give us a mission and platform within which to explore various technologies as we bring in experts to present them. Several things need to come together to get this started:

1) Hardware: Mike C and I are looking into FPGA platform options.

2) We need to decide on a design language. Rodrigo and Eddie have some experience w/ compiling algorithms to GPGPUs. OpenCL might be an interesting technology to explore and would allow us to target FPGA as well as GPGPU and CPU. RTL is an obvious possibility. I can provide a long list of others. I'll be getting folks excited about TL-Verilog in a future meeting. It might be good to choose a simple design so we can try various languages for comparison. (Coincidentally, I have a colleague working on a paper focused on HDL characteristics.)

3) We need to choose a design to work on. Eddie has some interesting bioinformatics algorithms that might be fun to explore together. There is also interest in implementing a simple CPU core. Or a simulation of some sort might be fun.

Let's meet to discuss these options. Join us and help shape our project to one that interests you.

This meeting will likely focus mostly on options for the design we will implement. Eddie will present his algorithms as one option, and we will discuss others.

Bring your ideas.
results.name: Discuss options for a group FPGA design

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time (and returning) guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.

results.description:
You're on the trail, slip and twist your ankle...

Climbing the mountain down and tweak your knee...

Push it too hard and feel those burning calves....

Did you know that your help might be growing right at your feet!?

Caring for a sprained ankle, twisted knee, or strained wrist requires two things: skillful bandaging technique and a knowledge of herbs which can accelerate the healing process. In this class we’ll demonstrate and practice reliable, effective wrapping for common injury sites. We’ll also familiarize you with herbs that can reduce inflammation, improve circulation, and restore healthy tissue quality to damaged connective tissues, as well as how to deliver them – as liniment, salve, poultice, etc.

Solomon’s seal is key remedy for the restoration of healthy tension in compromised tendons and ligaments.

When the emergency room is accessible, that may be your best option. If you’re out in the wilderness or if public services are compromised, though, you’re on your own – so come learn how to handle these issues yourself, with confidence!

Wednesday, February 10th, 2016
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.

http://commonwealthherbs.com/joint-healing-herbs-class/

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours.  Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here: https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week.  This part usually takes about 15 minutes.  The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!"  Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join.  It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in.  Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.

Please join us as we explore topics presented in Linda Howe’s Book, How to Read the Akashic Records. The Akashic Record study group is intended to support your learning process in accessing the Akashic Records through The Pathway Prayer Process©. 

Using the three levels of healing, we’ll discover how our work in the Records allows us to understand our true essence as eternal wholeness from the perspective of our soul. During class, we’ll engage in guided meditations that will support deeper access into the Records as well as opportunities for developing greater levels of skill in using the Pathway Prayer Process. Ordinary human struggles with relationships, reoccurring patterns of behavior, and emotional blocks will present opportunities to grow in recognizing the soul level truth of who we are, perfect in every way. Group includes open Records exercises as well as opportunities for practice readings with others.

The book How to Read the Akashic Records: Accessing the Archive of the Soul and Its Journey by Linda Howe is required for the class. If you haven't read the book but are working through the CD set or have taken Linda's basic training, you are welcome to attend.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

results.description:
NEW LOCATION - ALEWIFE PANERA. $20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we discuss the hottest economic topic of last year; paying employees a minimum wage of $15.00 per hour to screw up your order.

Please note the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], with any questions.

READINGS: 

1) http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-minimumwage-idUSKBN0UF1QA20160101


2) https://newrepublic.com/article/129286/raising-minimum-wage-wont-reduce-inequality


3)https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/minimum-wage-offensive-could-speed-arrival-of-robot-powered-restaurants/2015/08/16/35f284ea-3f6f-11e5-8d45-d815146f81fa_story.html

4)  http://newsexaminer.net/food/mcdonalds-to-open-restaurant-run-by-robots/


QUESTIONS:


1) According to the National Conference of State Legislatures, which states saw the greatest increase in the minimum wage? How about the least?

2) Which industry employs the greatest number of minimum wage earners?

3) What are the minimum wage fallacies and which economic principles do they ignore?

4) How do companies offset the cost of paying higher wages? 

5) Does the minimum wage reduce inequality?

6) What are popular alternatives to increasing the minimum wage, according to the New Republic article?

7) How are companies utilizing labor-saving technology, and what prompted this course of action?

8) What is a restaurant’s greatest competitive advantage, regarding their use of labor-saving technology?

9) According to the National Restaurant Association, what is the remaining challenge in the hospitality industry?

10) What is unique about the McDonald’s on 7th Street & McDowell Road in downtown Phoenix, Arizona?
results.name: The Minimum Wage Plight Of The American Worker

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!
results.how_to_find_us: We're meeting on the second floor in the Kuumba Library.  Enter the main entrance on Clarendon Street, take the spiral staircase to the right, and we're in the room to the right.  See you there!

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: Hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming session are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars as the cartel's leader is absence due to Family Growth.


Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
• Do you love being a mother but often feel drained with a sense that something is missing? 

• Does your work, family, and household obligations come before taking care of yourself? 

• Do you feel exhausted and pulled in a million different directions?

Join Coach Paula Sacco’s interactive workshop and learn tools and strategies to make the choices that will help make your needs a priority. Connect with other mothers in a supportive environment as you learn how to make more time in your day and create a more balanced life.


Paula Sacco, CPCC is a Certified Professional Life Coach who specializes in helping mothers find more time and balance in their lives while reducing stress and guilt as they learn how to self-prioritize. She coaches clients individually and conducts local and corporate workshops. Paula graduated from Babson College, received her MBA from Northeastern University and her coaching certification from Coaches Training Institute. She lives in Lexington with her husband and three children.

“Before Paula’s workshop I was feeling lost and overwhelmed. Through her workshop I have developed a new fresh perspective, confidence and the skills necessary to create purpose – both short and long term.” - Elizabeth Gibby-Homnick, Lexington MA

Enjoy wine and appetizers throughout the workshop.

results.description:
This is a free workshop-Have you ever wondered what Reiki is, thought about becoming a Reiki practitioner or just wanted to experience a Reiki session? 

Join Reiki Master Elaine Tavis for a informative talk on Reiki, how it works, its benefits and how to become a Certified Reiki practitioner. Our certified Reiki practitioners  will give as many mini Reiki sessions as time will allow.

This Meetup is free but you must register as space is limited. Doors will open at 6:45. For more about Essence of Healing go to www.essencehealing.net

What is Reiki…..
Reiki (Ray-Key) a Japanese word meaning "Universal Life Energy," is a gentle, powerful, effective touch therapy.
Reiki can be described as "energy nutrition" connecting mind/body/spirit as a whole creating many beneficial effects including relaxation and feelings of peace, security, and well-being.
• One of the greatest of reiki’s health benefits is stress-reduction and relaxation - triggering the body’s natural healing abilities, and improves and maintains health. Reiki healing is a natural therapy that gently balances life energies and brings health and well being to the recipient.
• This simple, non-invasive healing system works with the Higher Self of the receiver to promote health and well-being of the entire physical, emotional and psychic body. Therefore it is truly a system of attaining and promoting wholeness of mind/body/spirit.
• Reiki is a specific type of subtle energy work in which healing is performed by the touch of the hands, allowing the flow of the energy from a limitless source to the recipient via the reiki practitioner. Reiki is an extremely powerful yet gentle energy that can be easily channeled to yourself and others, even by simple intention.
• Reiki healing is a pure energy form. When it is combined with the sincere desire of the recipient who is willing to effect a cleansing within their emotional and spiritual consciousness - a total healing can occur.
results.name: EXPLORING REIKI: LEARN WHAT REIKI IS & EXPERIENCE A MINI REIKI SESSION

This is a program for those interested in accessing and maintaining higher consciousness. Much of the evening is in silence as you receive 3 crown chakra activations to lift and expand your energy field, bringing you to a felt sense of union with divine Source energy. Expect to feel profound peace, openness, expansion, and love.  As all Lightbearers are invited and needed to extend and help hold higher vibrations for others on the planet, part of this class will include using meditation, intention and imagery to spread the vibrations we receive.


Sacred l music plays for the entire evening.  Expect to maintain higher consciousness, giving you a sense of non-dual awareness....being with what is...total acceptance of everything within you and outside of you.

We are all in our awakening process...becoming awake to the Presence within us and living, speaking, loving and creating from that place. To access and maintain that truth of who we really are requires us to let go of any limiting beliefs, habits, memories. Then we can more fully embrace and embody the higher consciousness of our true Self.

Judy guides this class based on her ongoing deep studies and experiences with conscious awakening.  The sweet, profound results of expansion in consciousness occurs in moments. At these meetings we can freely express and connect with like-hearted souls as we share in these powerful energy transmissions. All are welcome to join us and share your own experience of conscious awakening...your challenges, inspirations, intentions and joys. If being in sacred energy appeals to you, you will love this gathering..


"So much peace, it's amazing."

We usually end up sitting in left-middle section of the balcony, since this affords a good view of the entire orchestra, is open to the ceiling, and is easy to describe and find, and it is relatively easy to grab a large block of seats there.

Directions to Jordan Hall: 
The hall is located at the corner of Huntington and Gainsborough streets, about a block south of the Symphony T stop on the Green Line. Look for the building with the YMCA sign on top of it--it's near that building. The main entrance is reached from Gainsborough Street.

Price: Free 

Location: NEC's Jordan Hall

NEC's FREE concerts do not require a ticket, unless stated in concert listing. Unreserved seating is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Doors open 30 minutes prior to the concert's start time.

Ensemble: NEC Philharmonia

Conductor: Hugh Wolff

Artist: Luke Hsu (Violin)

This season, NEC's orchestra programs allow you to discover the music of living composers, alongside familiar masterworks.

The centennial of composer Henri Dutilleux (1916–2013) is being marked by performances of his music at NEC and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. This results in a great opportunity to hear two great orchestras perform Métaboles, which is on BSO programs starting April 21—or simply to increase your exposure to this too-seldom-performed composer, who also appears on BSO programs starting January 14 and February 25.

Luke Hsu, chosen by competition as tonight's soloist in Lalo's Symphonie espagnole, is completing his second graduate program at NEC as a student of Donald Weilerstein.

results.description:
Are we animals?  Are we bodies?  Bodies with souls?  Souls with bodies?  At what point do I start or stop being me?  Are there things that I can do or can be done to me that are de-humanizing?  What does that mean about what it means to be human?

Are some people more human (or humane) than others?  How do we become better at it.  

What is humanism?  How does that relate to the question of being human?  

I think therefore I am.  I'm a sentient being.  But a dog thinks and feels and isn't human.  I get hungry, like other animals.  I feel emotional responses to situations. I have hopes and dreams.  I long to give and receive love.  I reflect on these things and "meetup" with others to discuss them.  Does that make us human?

Hope you can make it. -J

results.description:
Emotions

In what way does the development of the emotional life relate to a work toward consciousness—toward an integrated identity that is dynamic and challenging for oneself and genuinely helpful to others? The Gurdjieff teaching offers a map of human being that gives the emotional center as much importance as the intellectual and moving/instinctive centers. That map serves best as a guide for self-observation: we learn what we are, even from moment to moment. The life of the feelings, ranging from triggered reactions to deeply felt knowledge, is there to be discovered.   

The emotional center doesn’t yield its secrets easily. Emotions are quicker and more subtle than movement and thinking. Their language needs to be understood. How is it possible in practice to move toward this understanding? And what is the role of attention in this process of questioning and discovery?

Many emotions are what they are: ordinary, not so interesting or revealing. But sometimes a feeling appears that is immediately recognized as a different quality of knowing accompanied by a new experience of self—of one’s identity. These moments of finer quality can serve as a guide in the direction of self-study, deeper questioning, and relatedness. Gurdjieff once described the emotions as potentially a means of knowing. What a promising idea, that emotional awareness can develop into a unique way of knowing, appreciating, and direction-finding. On the other hand, he promised work. Referring to the emotions he said, “The horse must change.”

We welcome your questions.

results.description:
https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant 
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen 

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish? 
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice. 
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls! 
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle. 

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones 
The Veg Coach 
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below. 

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats 
by Ellen Jaffe Jones 

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips 
1/2 cup puffed quinoa 
4 teaspoons coconut oil 
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional) 

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips 
1/2 cup puffed quinoa 
4 teaspoons coconut oil 
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional) 

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen. 
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet. 
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving. 
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Java is the precursor to learning Android Development. By learning Java you will have a better understanding of Android Development, and how it works. Learning to code, programming, and development can be challenging. By learning with a group it is said you are more motivated to learn, and more likely to complete what you started. Hopefully you will join us...  

We are going to be taking the Udacity course: 

Intro to Java Programming 
Building Programs with Classes & Objects

YOU CAN GET STARTED >>>>>>>>HERE


Course summary 
In this introductory course, you’ll learn, and practice essential computer science concepts using the Java programming language. You’ll learn about Object Oriented Programming, a technique that allows you to use code written by other programmers in your own programs. You’ll put your new Java programming skills to the test by solving real-world problems faced by software engineers.


Why Take This Course?  
Java is one of the most popular programming languages used by software developers today. It is the core language used in developing Android apps, and is also commonly used in back-end web development. If you’re new to programming and want to enter either of these fields, this course is a great place to get started.

Even if you don’t have a career trajectory in mind, Java programming is a great option for first-time coders due to its popularity and ease of use. This course will provide you with a solid foundation in computer science and Object Oriented Programming concepts, as well as set you on the path for success as a software engineer.


Prerequisites and Requirements
No prior programming experience and knowledge is assumed or needed. Beginners welcome!

See the Technology Requirements for using Udacity.


Syllabus 

Lesson 1: Introduction to Computers, Programming Languages, Algorithms, and the Java Programming Environment

Lesson 2: Introduction to Classes and Objects


Lesson 3: Graphics


Lesson 4: Fundamental Data Types


Lesson 5: Decisions

Lesson 6: Iterations

Lesson 7: Arrays, ArrayLists and Simple Array Algorithms


Lesson 8: Methods (Parameter Passing, Instance vs. Static Methods)

Lesson 9: Inheritance 

This will be a 4 month commitment, assuming you dedicate 6 hrs/wk and work at your own pace.  

You will want to post your progress on our Discussion Forum found on our message board section as you complete lessons. You can use this as resource, and get help among your peers as well. Post your work, and progress here..

For immediate help we will also be using Slack a collaboration tool for teams. Our Slack channel is Android Boston. If you are not already on our Slack channel you can ask for an invite here.    

A special thanks to Udacity for providing this great free resource to get started!
results.name: Virtual Study: Intro to Java Programming

results.description:
Save the time and date: Thursday February 11,    2016, 12:30pm, somewhere in N. Cambridge. 


Remember when you worked in an office,and they gave you some time to eat lunch in the cafeteria, and you actually pulled yourself away from your desk and went and ate lunch with other people? Nah, I don't remember that either, but it sure sounds like fun. And, it's the law. If your employer denied you a lunch break, you'd be filing a complaint with the state so fast. About 25 people expressed interest, which means that probably five to eight people will show up. 

The others will all have good excuses, such as, "It's too cold," "I'm too tired," "I have too much work," "I have a deadline," "my clients need me," etc. I don't want to hear your excuses, Please don't bore me with those lame-o excuses, I just want you to show up. it will be at some eatery near Mass Ave in Arlington. I will call tom'w and see if there's some place good that can accommodate eight of us for lunch. RSVP by obtaining a free ticket at eventrbire, first come, first served:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/thursday-211-collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-location-n-cambridge-tickets-21070692007


that way I'll know you're coming, and be able to contact you easily. That will also help to limit the attendance. If you think this idea can fly, please do sign up and show up, and then we can repeat this pleasure again next week. bests,


-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

4Buyers RE

results.description:
In 2016, our Thursday night workshops will run in six-week blocks, four times in the year. This session is our last workshop of the winter!

New members are always welcome. We'll be prepared to discuss work in any genre, prose or verse. Bring enough copies of the text you’d like to discuss for each workshop attendee to have their own. If you do not have the means to make copies, send the text by attachment to bostonpoetryunion (at) gmail (dot) com not later than the night before the workshop.

Occasionally, the moderator will invite a member or guest speaker to open the session with a brief talk on some literary topic. If you’re interested in delivering such a talk, email the organizers and let them know! We are similarly open to suggestions for writing exercises, discussions at members' homes, visits to readings or bookstores, and other events of interest to writers.

NB: At the 5th session of this season's series, we agreed upon an assignment for the 6th session: writing a ballad form (however defined), that makes use of "found language" appropriated or quoted from news media (whatever the source). This is not a required assignment, of course; just a prompt for those who like to exercise their creativity with a starting point.

ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: Now in its 14th year, the weekly Boston Poetry workshop (formerly “Charles River Writers”) is an open, accessible, and welcoming forum for literary fellowship and discussion.

results.description:
We gather every month for engaging presentations, lively discussions and food/beer! This group gives security researchers in the Greater Boston community the chance to interact with each other more frequently. Each event features three speakers to talk about something a good hacker finds interesting along with discussions about security processes, techniques and much more!

We'll meet at the LogMeIn Offices at 333 Summer St in the Seaport District close to South Station. 

Cybersecurity Opener 

by Akshat Pradhan

This will be a quick talk to introduce our speakers, sponsors, and agenda. We'll also discuss some topics related to security compliance, including a recent HIPAA violation where an API exposed records of unaffiliated patients to Hospital employees. 

Privacy News of the Month: What's in your file?

by James O'Keefe

The Snowden revelations give us a decent idea of what the NSA knows about you. Add in increasing corporate surveillance to better target ads and you, and your privacy is increasingly moot. James O'Keefe will give a quick survey of what your permanent record looks like and why you should worry about it. 

Tool of the Month

by Will Lefevers 

Will Lefevers, Our Tool, does a lightning talk round about a security tool. A light demo is always sure to delight Red Teamers and Blue Teamers.

1. Digitization, Privacy and Government Surveillance (6:45-7:05)

By Alex Marthews | LinkedIn | Twitter

Moving from an analog to a digital economy has created staggering opportunities for mass digital government surveillance, but mass surveillance is bedeviled by extraordinarily high volume, high false positive rates, graft, lack of oversight and, in common with any algorithmic system, contamination from the assumptions used to program the system. This talk will give an overview of US (and some Five Eyes) surveillance programs, the legal and constitutional questions they arouse, their effects on ordinary political activities, and strategies to circumvent and undermine them.

About Alex. Restore The Forth's National Chair, Alex Marthews is deep in the thick of battles on Capitol Hill to rein in the PATRIOT Act, and on Beacon Hill to increase police accountability. Alex previously ran nonprofits addressing poverty, housing, and girls' education in East Africa, and interned with EFF back when it was much smaller. He moved to Boston from San Jose in 2005, and gives regular talks on surveillance policy and activism. He is also the co-author of a well-known study on the effects of the Snowden revelations on internet search behavior.

2.  Where Digital Security and Privacy Rights Intersect (7:10-7:30)

by Max Bauer | LinkedIn | Twitter

The framers designed a Constitution which prioritized freedom from "unreasonable" searches and from self-incrimination. These are bedrock principles and fundamental rights in a free society. But what makes a search "unreasonable" when it comes to digital metadata, GPS location tracking, and iPhones? And how do courts conceptualize encryption, which seems to be somewhere between incriminating testimony and a traditional lock? Clearly our founding fathers did not foresee the privacy concerns we have with twenty-first century technology.  This talk will discuss how courts have determined (and struggled with) how to apply modern and quickly evolving technology to a legal framework established centuries earlier. From the U.S. Supreme Court's decisions on thermal imaging, GPS, and cell phone searches, to the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court's decisions on CSLI and decryption, this talk explains the current state of the law and lays a foundation for where it is headed.

About Max. An associate attorney with White & Associates, P.C., Max Bauer addresses a wide range of substantive and procedural issues in the realm of criminal defense and privacy rights law.  He recently presented for Massachusetts Continuing Legal Education on the intersection between constitutional rights and modern technology at the program "When Cell Phones Become Evidence." Although he has a limited technical security background, he has hosted a cryptoparty on Tor, SSL, and PGP.

3. Separating the Bots from the Humans (7:35-7:55) 

by Ryan Mitchell | LinkedIn | Twitter

Web scrapers are often thought of as purely data collection tools; however, they can be used to probe large collections of websites for vulnerabilities and exploit found weaknesses, and they are often unfazed by traditional “solutions” like robots.txt files, AJAX loading, and even CAPTCHAs. This presentation will provide an overview of what separates the bots from the humans and give examples of how scrapers/bots can be used alongside more traditional tools to both attack and defend websites.

About Ryan. Ryan Mitchell is a software engineer at LinkeDrive in Boston, where she develops their API and data analysis tools. She is a graduate of Olin College of Engineering and is a master's degree student at Harvard University School of Extension Studies. Prior to joining LinkeDrive, she built web scrapers and bots as a software engineer at Abine, Inc. She continues to work as a freelancer building web scrapers for clients, primarily in financial and retail industries, and she volunteers weekly at the Boston Museum of Science in the Engineering Design Workshop.

Ryan is the author of two books: Instant Web Scraping with Java (Packt Publishing, 2013) and Web Scraping with Python (O’Reilly Media, 2015). 


Schedule

6:00 - 6:30: Food & Beer

6:30 - 6:35: Cybersecurity Opener by Akshat

6:35 - 6:40: Privacy News by James

6:40 - 6:45: Tool of the month by Will 

6:45 - 7:05:   Separating the Bots from the Humans by Ryan Mitchell

7:10 - 7:30:  Where Digital Security and Privacy Rights Intersect by Max Bauer

7:35 - 7:55:  Digitization, Privacy and Government Surveillance by Alex Marthews

Network with other security enthusiasts!

Physical Security 

We'd like to make things easy for Security. Everybody should update their meetup profile with their last name and a recent photograph. To do that, click My Profile > View Profile and you'll see the options.

Parking  

Parking is available around the area. A few garages can be found by searching for Seaport Parking. You can also just get off at South Station and walk across the bridge.  Channelside Parking Lot - 284 A St, Boston, MA 02210 for the GPS. $8.00 evening rate if you enter the lot after 3pm. Note on the parking for those not familiar with the area - Channelside Lot and Necco Garage are close by and fairly decent. Channelside is a few dollars cheaper though.

Not receiving emails? 

Some members have said they're not receiving our emails. You might have unsubscribed to our special announcements. To fix it: Click Settings > Email Updates > Choose Boston Security Meetup under "Updates about your groups" and check off "Announcement about a specific Meetup" and "Announcement to members about the group".

Why are you charging $1?  

The nominal $1 fee and checkout process serve to verify your attendance and provide a more accurate headcount — and ensure a much better networking experience! Your modest support does enable and encourage us to continue improving these events.

Looking for speakers! 

We're always looking for good speakers and interesting topics for our presentation nights! If you're interested in giving a talk, or have a suggestion for a future event, please contact us. 

Recruiters 

Boston Security Meetup appreciate's your interest in our events, however, we've noticed a significant rise in the number of recruiters. After this event, we're asking you to reach out directly to us and sponsor before attending our events. Please PM for specific details and we appreciate your understanding!

results.description:
This year I’m starting something a little new. Mindful eating is about eating with awareness. Awareness helps people to have a better sense of when they are hungry and when they are full, when they overeat, what cues them to overeat, and what types of situations or environmental factors make overeating more likely to happen. Mindfully eating is typically thought of as slowing down, tasting one’s food, pacing oneself and being able to appreciate food more. However, this is simply is not enough instruction for people who want more of a conscious approach to changing unhelpful eating habits. 

Recently I found the book Eating the Moment by Pavel Somov, Ph.D. This book offers 141 exercises to eat mindfully. They are clever, helpful, and experiential options to increase one’s awareness of eating. The mindful eating groups that I will be co-hosting will be based on these 141 exercises. My goal is to get through the entire book, but to find people who are interested in doing it with me. If you are interested in this journey, you must get the book. Every time we meet for dinner there will be 2-3 exercises to try during the week, and we will report on how they went for each of us. 

For this MeetUp I am asking people to read through the introductory material (if you haven't already) and read and complete pages 20-25. There are some "essays" to write regarding noticing the differences between hunger and craving cues.  Bear in mind that this involves some monitoring and tracking , so it is best to get started now if you want to be prepared to share your observations on Thursday. Remember that this is a group where participation is part of the process and there is no experiential learning if there is no experimenting/ doing/ trying. 

The Mindful Eating Meetups will be cohosted with other meetup groups, and will include locations on the North Shore as well as in and around Boston. We will try to meet consistently as there is more interest. That is also why the attendance may seem small or limited; because we are accommodating another group- the Cambridge Boston Ethnic dining group. As an FYI, this event will be mixed gender and may include men. 

In addition, here is an exercise that I would like participants to consider, in the overarching theme of awareness of ethnic diversity and food:

1)  Research the country of the ethnic food MeetUp group and make a list of current facts about the country. Consider facts that you find interesting or fascinating and share your facts with the group.

2)  Find a food or spice that the restaurant uses in its dishes and research any health benefits, uses for the food, or other interesting facts about the food. Introduce the food to the group. Share the unique aspects of this food/ spice and/ or recipe with the group. 

As always, I will document people who NO SHOW as a NO SHOW and move towards not letting you attend future events. So if you make a commitment, come.

results.name: Mindful Eating- Peruvian Fusion

From the SURJ Boston Facebook page:

Showing Up for Racial Justice- Boston is a volunteer run project of Community Change Inc and a chapter of a national network of groups and individuals organizing white people for racial justice.
SURJ Boston focuses on: Building community with people and organizations in the Boston area working to end racism; Supporting and taking action to end racism/White Supremacy; Welcoming people new to racial justice work and/or new to the Boston area; and Exploring the larger Strategy of anti-racist organizing.

Next month's meeting is planned for March 10.  The location may be different, but the times will likely be the same.

Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

This month, the Boston Clojure Group Meetups will be held at Akamai in the conference rooms 200A on the second floor.

Please join us for a night of Clojure related discussion and group activities.

Meet & Greet starts at 6:00. Group activities will begin at 6:30.

Future meeting ideas will be discussed over the meetup board and in our Google discussion group:  https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/boston-clojure .

Agenda: Coding Dojo: Contributing to Clojure open source projects

Description

"You - yes you! - can contribute to Clojure open source projects, and "give back" to the Clojure community - and you don't need years of Clojure experience to do it. This collaborative evening of practical, hands-on work will show you an example of a successful open source contributor's development cycle. We will break out into small groups and work on different projects. Feel free to think of projects you'd like to work on. We'll also have some suggested projects to work on e.g. leiningen, clojars.org or ring".

Bio

Gabriel Horner (@cldwalker) is a senior software engineer at Figly and a LightTable maintainer

results.description:
Our 2nd meetup will feature two prominent and dynamic speakers on how open source Big Data technologies lead to success. We have a new location at Jana to which we are grateful for their sponsorship.

Agenda:

6:30 - 7:00 - Networking

7:00 - 7:10 - Message from our sponsors

7:10 - 7:50 - Jeff Kelly - "Open Source is the better way"

7:55 - 8:45 - Louis Calisi - "Processing 200 billion XML lines/day at TripAdvisor"

8:45-9:00 - Thanks and ideas for next month's meetup


Talk #1: As mainstream enterprises start to get serious about Big Data analytics (BDA), they need to make a number of technology decisions that will have long term implications for the success or failure of their BDA projects. Among the most important decisions is whether to approach BDA with traditional, proprietary products or with open source frameworks and technologies. In this presentation, Pivotal's Jeff Kelly will discuss why an open source approach, though not without its challenges, is the better way to lay the technology foundation for extracting the most value from your data.

Bio: Jeff Kelly is a Big Data strategist at Pivotal Software. In this role, Jeff spends his time researching, writing and speaking about trends impacting Big Data analytics in the enterprise and best practices for success. Prior to joining Pivotal, Jeff was the lead Big Data analyst at research firm Wikibon, where he published the industry's first Big Data market forecast in 2012. Before that, Jeff was a technology journalist with TechTarget covering the data management and business intelligence markets.


Talk #2:  I've just wrapped up developing a system for Tripadvisor that uses Kafka and Samza to replace our existing ETL systems. It's currently processing about 200 billion lines of XML a day.

Bio: Louis Calisi is a Principal Software Engineer at TripAdvisor. Louis has 14 years of software engineering experience in a wide variety of industries and technologies.

results.name: Open Analytics talks

results.description:
This is Four Week Training in Beginners Qi Gong

Join Giftefor a 4 Week Introduction Practice of Qi Gong - Qi Gong provides a gentle journey relieving the following:

(No experience required)
Take control of your health and well-being at any age or fitness level by practicing Qi Gong, a system of Chinese movement that removes energy blockages in the body.  The emphasis of this class is to reduce stress, increase energy, quiet the mind, and enhance the immune system to bring the body into harmony and balance.

Qi Gong increases the body’s energy (Qi) through gentle stretching, low-impact movement, deep rhythmic breathing and acupressure massage. The slow, relaxed movements synchronized with gentle breathing and mindful intent help to relax and release tension, developing a stronger mind/body connection.  Practitioners of Qi Gong report less tension, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. Practicing Qi Gong can relieve many ailments such as: back, neck and shoulder problems, gastrointestinal conditions, arthritis, fibromyalgia, hypertension, low immune function, headaches, and insomnia.  Therapeutic Qi Gong exercise is a prescription for health, longevity, and happiness.

Bio
Patty Gage is a Certified Qi Gong Instructor trained by Dr. Aihan Kuhn, Qi Gong and Tai Chi Master at Chinese Medicine for Health. Patty was introduced to Qi Gong in 2008 by David Silver, a certified YMAA Qi Gong instructor on Cape Cod, MA and continues to practice with him.
results.name: Qi Gong Practice weekly for everyone

I don't know about all of you but I can use a good comedy....

Movie starts at 7:20- we will meet between 7-7:10

I think I have mastered the single life....so this should be interesting...lol  =)

Who would like to join me to see this move Thursday night?  I would like to at least have 5 folks RSVP by tomorrow (Wed) by 6pm in order to keep this up.  Right now I am aiming for the NON reserved seating to make it easier with a group.

Kim

Movie Synopsis

There's a right way to be single, a wrong way to be single, and then...there's Alice. And Robin. Lucy. Meg. Tom. David. New York City is full of lonely hearts seeking the right match, be it a love connection, a hook-up, or something in the middle. And somewhere between the teasing texts and one-night stands, what these unmarrieds all have in common is the need to learn how to be single in a world filled with ever-evolving definitions of love. Sleeping around in the city that never sleeps was never so much fun.

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.
results.name: Join us as we discuss A Course In Miracles and apply its principles to our lives

group.name: A Course In Miracles Discussion Group - Carlisle

results.description: Come check out dragon boating with Living Root! We're a co-ed dragon boat team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. This is a great way to get in shape, stay in shape, meet people, and do something fun and competitive. How to get there: We practice at the pool at the JFK Elementary School in Somerville. Walk through the outdoor basketball courts to the rear of the building to find the pool entrance. Take the stairs down to the ground floor and head through the locker rooms to get to the pool. Practice will begin poolside at 7 pm. Wear athletic clothing. Although we won't do any swimming, you will get somewhat wet. Parking is free in the school parking lot. The T station at Porter Square is a 5 minute walk away. Practice will last an hour and 45 minutes. We provide paddles and all the necessary equipment--just bring yourself! No paddling experience is required. We have an excellent coaching staff who will teach you everything you will need to know. We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice, and you're welcome to join us. Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked] [url=http://www.livingroot.org/]www.livingroot.org[/url]

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar or when the bartender comes around. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. The bartender will take your name with your order and associate your future requests with you name.

2) The bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. The bartender will associate your requests with you name. Please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

See you there!
~Lindsay
